title: Introduction to CropWaterBalance
text: Irrigated areas increased throughout globe support growing global population cope climate change impacts (@Siyal2023). context, {CropWaterBalance} allows users keep track soil water deficit root zone crop water balance accounting (@Andales2012). goal package assist users making decisions much irrigate. important function package CWB(), calculates several parameters crop water balance, including crop evapotranspiration (ETc), actual crop evapotranspiration, stored water root zone soil water deficit (D). function also suggests irrigate, considering management allowed depletion (MAD) provided users. Although FAO-Penman Monteith equation recognized standard method estimating daily amounts reference evapotranspiration (ETO) (@Allen1998), high number variables required calculating model limits operational use several regions world. Thus, package includes function ETO_PM(), estimate daily ETO amounts FAO-Penman Monteith equation, functions ETO_PT() ETO_HS()), calculates agrometeorological parameter two alternative (simpler) methods: Priestley-Taylor (@Priestley1972) Hargreaves-Samani (@Hargreaves1985), respectively. Additionally, {CropWaterBalance} two functions (Compare() Descriptive()). first calculates measures accuracy agreement two data samples second calculates descriptive statistics samples. Therefore, two functions assist users selecting suitable ET0 estimating methods particular region season.

title: Introduction to CropWaterBalance
text: Load library R session.
code: library(CropWaterBalance) #>  #> Attaching package: 'CropWaterBalance' #> The following object is masked from 'package:methods': #>  #>     Compare

what: Using ETO_PM() to calculate daily amounts of reference evapotranspiration
title: Introduction to CropWaterBalance
text: Reference evapotranspiration (ET0) combined process evaporation transpiration occurs well-fertilized disease-free hypothetical grass reference crop, grown large fields soil water restriction achieving full production (@Allen1998). ETO_PM() function calculates daily ETO amounts using FAO-Penman Monteith equation (millimetres).

what: Step 1: Applying ETO_PM() in Campinas-SP, Brazil
title: Introduction to CropWaterBalance
text: analyzing ET0_PM() function, user verify FAO-Penman Monteith equation requires several inputs, includes soil heat flux (G). latter variable rarely measure. reason {CropWaterBalance} auxiliary function (Soil_Heat_Flux()) estimates G function daily average air temperature values. users may use auxiliary function estimate G apply ET0_PM() function. Alternatively, users may simply run ET0_PM() without G argument. case, latter function automatically use Soil_Heat_Flux() estimate ETO. See example .
code: Tavg <- DataForCWB[, 2] Tmax <- DataForCWB[, 3] Tmin <- DataForCWB[, 4] Rn <- DataForCWB[, 6] WS <- DataForCWB[, 7] RH <- DataForCWB[, 8] G <- DataForCWB[, 9] CpsET0PM <-   ET0_PM(     Tavg = Tavg,     Tmax = Tmax,     Tmin = Tmin,     Rn = Rn,     RH = RH,     WS = WS,     G = G,     Alt = 700   ) head(CpsET0PM) #>        ET0_PM #> [1,] 2.440372 #> [2,] 4.171917 #> [3,] 4.290477 #> [4,] 3.665459 #> [5,] 4.848520 #> [6,] 5.669878 Tavg <- DataForCWB[, 2] Tmax <- DataForCWB[, 3] Tmin <- DataForCWB[, 4] Rn <- DataForCWB[, 6] WS <- DataForCWB[, 7] RH <- DataForCWB[, 8] G <- Soil_Heat_Flux(Tavg) #> Warning in Soil_Heat_Flux(Tavg): The first 3 G values were set to zero CpsET0PM_WithG <-   ET0_PM(     Tavg = Tavg,     Tmax = Tmax,     Tmin = Tmin,     Rn = Rn,     RH = RH,     WS = WS,     G = G,     Alt = 700   ) CpsET0PM_WithoutG <-   ET0_PM(     Tavg = Tavg,     Tmax = Tmax,     Tmin = Tmin,     Rn = Rn,     RH = RH,     WS = WS,     Alt = 700   ) #> Warning in Soil_Heat_Flux(Tavg): The first 3 G values were set to zero head(cbind(CpsET0PM_WithG, CpsET0PM_WithoutG)) #>        ET0_PM   ET0_PM #> [1,] 2.293183 2.293183 #> [2,] 4.104242 4.104242 #> [3,] 4.333359 4.333359 #> [4,] 3.665304 3.665304 #> [5,] 4.848440 4.848440 #> [6,] 5.670052 5.670052

what: Step 2: Applying ETO_PT() and ET0_HS() in Campinas-SP, Brazil
title: Introduction to CropWaterBalance
text: described introduction, users may need estimate ETO using non-standard methods, require less input FAO-Penman Monteith. {CropWaterBalance} allows users estimate agrometeorological parameter using Priestley-Taylor (ETO_PT()) Hargreaves-Samani (ET0_HS()) methods. Note considerations made G respect ETO_PM() valid ETO_PT(). estimation CpsET0PT /CpsET0HS raises following question: Can alternative methods really replace FAO-Penman Monteith model? Although answer question may regarded complex function involving local weather conditions users’ subjective choices, (Compare()) (Descriptive()) functions provide statistical information, may assist users decision. context, Compare() Descriptive() functions may used verify well alternative ET0 estimating method approaches ET0_PM. results provided Compare() Descriptive() functions, indicate none two alternative methods can used replace calculating daily ET0 amounts. instance, values modified index agreement (dmod) (@Willmott1985) remained 0.4 comparisons (PM vs PT) (PM vs HS). Additionally, corresponding absolute mean errors (AME; 1.69222 1.468722) represents, approximately, 50% 43% average value ET0_PM (3.367377).
code: Tavg <- DataForCWB[, 2] Tmax <- DataForCWB[, 3] Tmin <- DataForCWB[, 4] Ra <- DataForCWB[, 5] Rn <- DataForCWB[, 6] G <- DataForCWB[, 9] CpsET0PT <- ET0_PT(Tavg = Tavg, Rn = Rn, G = G) CpsET0HS <- ET0_HS(   Ra = Ra,   Tavg = Tavg,   Tmax = Tmax,   Tmin = Tmin ) head(cbind(CpsET0PT, CpsET0HS)) #>        ET0_PT      ET0 #> [1,] 3.432709 4.703700 #> [2,] 5.849554 5.331592 #> [3,] 6.432616 5.664174 #> [4,] 5.695334 6.163377 #> [5,] 7.023900 5.291303 #> [6,] 7.817355 6.251883 Tavg <- DataForCWB[, 2] Tmax <- DataForCWB[, 3] Tmin <- DataForCWB[, 4] Ra <- DataForCWB[, 5] Rn <- DataForCWB[, 6] WS <- DataForCWB[, 7] RH <- DataForCWB[, 8] G <- DataForCWB[, 9] CpsET0PM <-   ET0_PM(     Tavg = Tavg,     Tmax = Tmax,     Tmin = Tmin,     Rn = Rn,     RH = RH,     WS = WS,     G = G,     Alt = 700   ) CpsET0PT <- ET0_PT(Tavg = Tavg, Rn = Rn, G = G) CpsET0HS <- ET0_HS(   Ra = Ra,   Tavg = Tavg,   Tmax = Tmax,   Tmin = Tmin ) PM_PT <- Compare(Sample1 = CpsET0PM, Sample2 = CpsET0PT) PM_PT #>       AME     RMSE     dorig     dmod        dref     RQuad #> 1 1.69222 1.813449 0.6403158 0.376103 -0.05737454 0.8675223 Descrp_PM_PT <-   cbind(Descriptive(Sample = CpsET0PM), Descriptive(Sample = CpsET0PT)) Descrp_PM_PT #>   SampleSize  Avg  Med   SD   SE MaxValue MinValue FreqZero% SampleSize  Avg #> 1        129 3.37 3.46 0.97 0.09     5.76     1.26         0        129 5.06 #>    Med   SD   SE MaxValue MinValue FreqZero% #> 1 5.22 1.46 0.13     8.15     2.14         0 PM_HS <- Compare(Sample1 = CpsET0PM, Sample2 = CpsET0HS) PM_HS #>        AME     RMSE     dorig      dmod       dref     RQuad #> 1 1.468722 1.630292 0.6033421 0.3818204 0.07924634 0.5546701 Descrp_PM_HS <-   cbind(Descriptive(Sample = CpsET0PM), Descriptive(Sample = CpsET0HS)) Descrp_PM_HS #>   SampleSize  Avg  Med   SD   SE MaxValue MinValue FreqZero% SampleSize  Avg #> 1        129 3.37 3.46 0.97 0.09     5.76     1.26         0        129 4.82 #>    Med   SD  SE MaxValue MinValue FreqZero% #> 1 5.11 1.09 0.1     6.73     2.25         0

what: Step 3: The Crop Water Balance Accounting. Applying InitialD() and CWB() in Campinas-SP, Brazil
title: Introduction to CropWaterBalance
text: Considering previous results, applied CWB() using daily values rainfall ET0_PM obtained/estimated daily data weather station Campinas. included meteorological data package (DataForCWB), along parameters required calculating crop water balance: depth root zone (Drz), available water capacity (AWC; amount water field capacity permanent wilting point), management allowed depletion (MAD), crop coefficient (Kc). example loaded DataForCWB apply CWB() Campinas-SP. sake simplicity, Kc values set 1 entire period. initial D value (Dinitial) required initiating crop water balance account obtained using function DInitial() teta_FC AWC values obtained two data sets included package (DataForSWC.rda DataForAWC). data sets provide soil water content values (m3/m3) effective root zone field capacity permanent wilting point, AWC values (mm/m), respectively (teta_obs measured field). applied CWB() function considering two scenarios. Scenario 1 irrigation applied scenario 2 package’s recommendation much irrigate met. scenarios, package suggested irrigating 29/11/2011 soil water deficit become larger dmad. Since scenario 1 applied irrigation, Ks coefficient started assume values smaller 1 NonStandardCropEvap becomes smaller ETc, may prevent crop achieving potential yield. scenario 2, followed package’s recommendation applied irrigation day 29 (Irrig = 16 mm). case, crop evapotranspiration deficit observed, indicating water shortage root zone.

what: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Crop water balance accounting root zone irrigation purposes.

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: {CropWaterBalance} R package designed assist users irrigation scheduling based Water Balance Approach. package capable calculating reference evapotranspiration (ET0) various methods conducting crop water balance accounting. Additionally, {CropWaterBalance} includes auxiliary functions comparing different ET0 estimation methods, calculating descriptive statistics ET0 rainfall series, estimating soil heat flux water stress coefficient. functions ET0_HS(), ET0_PT(), ET0_PM() used estimate daily ET0 amounts using methods Hargreaves-Samani, Priestley-Taylor, FAO-56 Penman-Monteith, respectively. Descriptive() function specifically designed calculate descriptive statistics ET0 rainfall series, including sample mean, median, standard deviation, standard error, maximum value, minimum value, frequency zeros. Additionally, Compare() function may used calculate measures accuracy agreement two ET0 rainfall series. Soil_Heat_Flux() function uses average air temperature data estimate soil heat flux, Water_Stress_Coef() function calculates water stress coefficient crop. package depends R (>= 2.10) imports functions R packages {PowerSDI} {lubridate}.

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Calculates daily reference evapotranspiration amounts using Penman Monteith method.

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
code: ET0_PM(Tavg,   Tmax,   Tmin,   Rn,   RH,   WS,   G = NULL,   Alt )

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Tavg: vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily average air temperature. Tmax: vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily maximum air temperature Celsius degrees. Tmin: vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily minimum air temperature Celsius degrees. Rn: vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily net radiation MJ M-2 DAY-1. RH: vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily relative Humidity %. WS: vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily wind speed M S-1. G: Optional. vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily soil heat flux MJ M-2 DAY-1. Default NULL NULL assumed zero. May provided Soil_Heat_Flux. Alt: single number defining altitude crop’s location metres.

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
code: Tavg <- DataForCWB[, 2] Tmax <- DataForCWB[, 3] Tmin <- DataForCWB[, 4] Rn <- DataForCWB[, 6] WS <- DataForCWB[, 7] RH <- DataForCWB[, 8] G <- DataForCWB[, 9] Sample1 <-   ET0_PM(     Tavg = Tavg,     Tmax = Tmax,     Tmin = Tmin,     Rn = Rn,     RH = RH,     WS = WS,     G = G,     Alt = 700   ) Sample2 <- ET0_PT(Tavg = Tavg, Rn = Rn, G = G) Compare(Sample1 = Sample1, Sample2 = Sample2) ##       AME     RMSE     dorig     dmod        dref     RQuad ## 1 1.69222 1.813449 0.6403158 0.376103 -0.05737454 0.8675223

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
code: CWB(   Rain,   ET0,   AWC,   Drz,   Kc = NULL,   Irrig = NULL,   MAD = NULL,   InitialD = 0,   start.date )

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Rain: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily rainfall totals millimetres. ET0: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily reference evapotranspiration millimetres. AWC: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame available water capacity soil, : amount water field capacity permanent wilting point millimetres water per centimetre soil. Drz: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining root zone depth centimetres. Kc: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining crop coefficient. NULL values assumed 1. Irrig: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame net irrigation amount infiltrated soil current day millimetres. MAD: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining management allowed depletion. Varies 0 1. InitialD Single number defining millimetre, initial soil water deficit. used start water balance accounting. Default value 0, assumes root zone field capacity. start.date: Date accounting start. Formats: “YYYY-MM-DD”, “YYYY/MM/DD”.

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Water balance accounting, including soil water deficit.

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
code: Tavg <- DataForCWB[, 2] Tmax <- DataForCWB[, 3] Tmin <- DataForCWB[, 4] Rn <- DataForCWB[, 6] WS <- DataForCWB[, 7] RH <- DataForCWB[, 8] G <- DataForCWB[, 9] ET0 <- ET0_PM(Tavg, Tmax, Tmin, Rn, RH, WS, G, Alt = 700) Rain <- DataForCWB[, 10] Drz <- DataForCWB[, 11] AWC <- DataForCWB[, 12] MAD <- DataForCWB[, 13] Kc <- DataForCWB[, 14] Irrig <- DataForCWB[, 15] head(CWB(   Rain = Rain,   ET0 = ET0,   AWC = AWC,   Drz = Drz,   Kc = Kc,   Irrig = Irrig,   MAD = MAD,   start.date = "2023-11-23" )) ##            DaysSeason Rain Irrig ET0 Kc WaterStressCoef_Ks ETc (P+Irrig)-ETc NonStandardCropEvap ET_Defict  TAW SoilWaterDeficit d_MAD D>=dmad ## 2023-11-22          1 45.5     0 2.4  1                  1 2.4          43.0                 2.4         0 45.7              0.0  13.7      No ## 2023-11-23          2  0.3     0 4.2  1                  1 4.2          -3.9                 4.2         0 45.7              3.9  13.7      No ## 2023-11-24          3  0.0     0 4.3  1                  1 4.3          -4.3                 4.3         0 45.7              8.2  13.7      No ## 2023-11-25          4 11.4     0 3.7  1                  1 3.7           7.8                 3.7         0 45.7              0.4  13.7      No ## 2023-11-26          5  0.3     0 4.8  1                  1 4.8          -4.6                 4.8         0 45.7              5.0  13.7      No ## 2023-11-27          6  0.0     0 5.7  1                  1 5.7          -5.7                 5.7         0 45.7             10.7  13.7      No

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Rain: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily rainfall totals millimetres. ET0: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily reference evapotranspiration millimetres. AWC: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame available water capacity soil, : amount water field capacity permanent wilting point millimetre water per centimetre soil. Drz: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining root zone depth centimetres. Kc: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining crop coefficient. NULL values assumed 1. Irrig: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame net irrigation amount infiltrated soil current day millimetres. MAD: Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining management allowed depletion. Varies 0 1. InitialD Single number defining millimetre, initial soil water deficit. used start water balance accounting. Default value 0, assumes root zone field capacity. Scheduling Single integer number defining number days two consecutive irrigations. start.date: Date accounting start. Formats: “YYYY-MM-DD”, “YYYY/MM/DD”.

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Water balance accounting, including soil water deficit.
code: Tavg <- DataForCWB[, 2] Tmax <- DataForCWB[, 3] Tmin <- DataForCWB[, 4] Rn <- DataForCWB[, 6] WS <- DataForCWB[, 7] RH <- DataForCWB[, 8] G <- DataForCWB[, 9] ET0 <- ET0_PM(Tavg, Tmax, Tmin, Rn, RH, WS, G, Alt = 700) Rain <- DataForCWB[, 10] Drz <- DataForCWB[, 11] AWC <- DataForCWB[, 12] MAD <- DataForCWB[, 13] Kc <- DataForCWB[, 14] Irrig <- DataForCWB[, 15] Scheduling <- 5 head(CWB_FixedSchedule(   Rain = Rain,   ET0 = ET0,   AWC = AWC,   Drz = Drz,   Kc = Kc,   Irrig = Irrig,   MAD = MAD,   Scheduling = Scheduling,   start.date = "2023-11-23" )) ##            DaysSeason   Rain Irrig   ET0 Kc WaterStressCoef_Ks   ETc (P+Irrig)-ETc NonStandardCropEvap ET_Defict   TAW SoilWaterDeficit  d_MAD            Scheduling ## 2023-11-22          1 45.470     0 2.440  1                  1 2.440        43.030               2.440         0 45.72            0.000 13.716                    No ## 2023-11-23          2  0.254     0 4.172  1                  1 4.172        -3.918               4.172         0 45.72            3.918 13.716                    No ## 2023-11-24          3  0.000     0 4.290  1                  1 4.290        -4.290               4.290         0 45.72            8.208 13.716                    No ## 2023-11-25          4 11.430     0 3.665  1                  1 3.665         7.765               3.665         0 45.72            0.444 13.716                    No ## 2023-11-26          5  0.254     0 4.849  1                  1 4.849        -4.595               4.849         0 45.72            5.038 13.716 Time to Irrigate 5 mm ## 2023-11-27          6  0.000     0 5.670  1                  1 5.670        -5.670               5.670         0 45.72           10.708 13.716                    No

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Gabriel Constantino Blain, Graciela da Rocha Sobierajski, Regina Célia Matos Pires, Adam H. Sparks, Letícia L. Martins. Maintainer: Gabriel Constantino Blain, gabriel.blain@sp.gov.br

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: package uses data Fact Sheet number 4707 Irrigation Scheduling: Water Balance Approach, . . Andales, J. L. Chávez, T. . Bauder. authors greatly appreciate initiative.

title: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes
text: Allen, R.G.; Pereira, L.S.; Raes, D.; Smith, M. Crop evapotranspiration. Guidelines Computing Crop Water Requirements. Irrigation Drainage Paper 56; FAO: Rome, Italy, 1998; p. 300. Andales, ..; Chávez, J.L.;Bauder, T.. 2012. Irrigation Scheduling: Water Balance Approach. Fact Sheet number 4707, crop series | irrigation. https://extension.colostate.edu/docs/pubs/crops/04707.pdf Hargreaves, G.H.; Samani, Z.. 1985.Reference crop evapotranspiration temperature. Appl. Eng. Agric,1, 96–99. Package ‘lubridate’, Version 1.9.3, Author Vitalie Spinu et al., https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=lubridate Package ‘PowerSDI’, Version 1.0. 0, Author Gabriel C. Blain et al., https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=PowerSDI Priestley, C.H.B., Taylor, R.J., 1972. Assessment Surface Heat Flux Evaporation Using Large-Scale Parameters. Monthly Weather Review, 100 (2), 81–92.

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting — CWB
text: Calculates several parameters crop water balance.  also suggests irrigate.

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting — CWB
code: CWB(   Rain,   ET0,   AWC,   Drz,   Kc = NULL,   Irrig = NULL,   MAD = NULL,   InitialD = 0,   start.date )

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting — CWB
text: Rain vector, 1-column matrix data.frame daily rainfall totals millimetres. ET0 vector, 1-column matrix data.frame daily reference evapotranspiration millimetres. AWC vector, 1-column matrix data.frame available water capacity soil, : amount water field capacity permanent wilting point millimetre water per metres soil, must greater equal 0. Drz vector, 1-column matrix data.frame defining root zone depth metres. Kc vector, 1-column matrix data.frame defining crop coefficient. NULL values assumed 1. Irrig vector, 1-column matrix data.frame  net irrigation amount infiltrated soil current day millimetres. MAD vector, 1-column matrix data.frame defining management allowed depletion.  Varies 0 1. InitialD Single number defining millimetres, initial soil water deficit.  used start water balance accounting.  Default value 0, assumes root zone field capacity. start.date Date accounting start. Formats: “YYYY-MM-DD”, “YYYY/MM/DD”.

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting — CWB
text: data.frame water balance accounting, including soil water deficit.

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting — CWB

what: Crop Water Balance Accounting With Fixed Time Periods for Irrigation — CWB_FixedSchedule
title: Crop Water Balance Accounting With Fixed Time Periods for Irrigation — CWB_FixedSchedule
text: Calculates several parameters crop water balance. also suggests much irrigation apply.

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting With Fixed Time Periods for Irrigation — CWB_FixedSchedule
code: CWB_FixedSchedule(   Rain,   ET0,   AWC,   Drz,   Kc = NULL,   Irrig = NULL,   MAD = NULL,   InitialD = 0,   Scheduling,   start.date )

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting With Fixed Time Periods for Irrigation — CWB_FixedSchedule
text: Rain Vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily rainfall totals millimetres. ET0 Vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily reference evapotranspiration millimetres. AWC Vector, 1-column matrix data frame available water capacity soil, : amount water field capacity permanent wilting point millimetres water per metres soil. Drz Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining root zone depth metres. Kc Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining crop coefficient. NULL values assumed 1. Irrig Vector, 1-column matrix data frame net irrigation amount infiltrated soil current day millimetres. MAD Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining management allowed depletion.  Varies 0 1. InitialD Single number defining millimetre, initial soil water deficit. used start water balance accounting. Default value zero, assumes root zone field capacity. Scheduling Single integer number defining number days two consecutive irrigations. start.date Date accounting start. Formats: “YYYY-MM-DD”, “YYYY/MM/DD”.

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting With Fixed Time Periods for Irrigation — CWB_FixedSchedule
text: Water balance accounting, including soil water deficit.

title: Crop Water Balance Accounting With Fixed Time Periods for Irrigation — CWB_FixedSchedule

what: Compare Data From Two Samples — Compare
title: Compare Data From Two Samples — Compare
text: Calculates measures accuracy agreement.

title: Compare Data From Two Samples — Compare
Compare Data From Two Samples — Compare
text: Sample1 vector, 1-column matrix data.frame evapotranspiration variable. Sample2 vector, 1-column matrix data.frame evapotranspiration variable.

title: Compare Data From Two Samples — Compare
text: data.frame : Absolute mean error (AME), square root mean squared error (RMSE), Willmott's indices agreement: original (dorig), modified (dmod) refined (dref) , Pearson determination coefficient (RQuad).

title: Compare Data From Two Samples — Compare
code: # See `?DataForCWB` for more on this data set Tavg <- DataForCWB[, 2] Tmax <- DataForCWB[, 3] Tmin <- DataForCWB[, 4] Rn <- DataForCWB[, 6] WS <- DataForCWB[, 7] RH <- DataForCWB[, 8] G <- DataForCWB[, 9] Sample1 <-   ET0_PM(     Tavg = Tavg,     Tmax = Tmax,     Tmin = Tmin,     Rn = Rn,     RH = RH,     WS = WS,     G = G,     Alt = 700) Sample2 <- ET0_PT(Tavg = Tavg, Rn = Rn, G = G) Compare(Sample1 = Sample1, Sample2 = Sample2) #>       AME     RMSE     dorig     dmod        dref     RQuad #> 1 1.69222 1.813449 0.6403158 0.376103 -0.05737454 0.8675223

what: CropWaterBalance: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes — CropWaterBalance-package
title: CropWaterBalance: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes — CropWaterBalance-package
text: Calculates daily climate water balance irrigation purposes also calculates reference evapotranspiration (ET) using three methods, Penman Monteith (Allen et al. 1998, ISBN:92-5-104219-5); Priestley Taylor (1972) doi:10/cr3qwn ; Hargreaves Samani (1985) doi:10.13031/2013.26773 . Users may specify management allowed depletion (MAD), used suggest irrigate. functionality allows use crop water stress coefficients well.

title: CropWaterBalance: Climate Water Balance for Irrigation Purposes — CropWaterBalance-package
text: Maintainer: Gabriel Constantino Blain gabriel.blain@sp.gov.br (ORCID) Authors: Graciela R. Sobierajski (ORCID) Regina C. Matos Pires (ORCID) Adam H. Sparks adamhsparks@gmail.com (ORCID) Leticia L. Martins (ORCID)

text: data frame 4 columns 12 rows: Soil.Texture Soil Texture AWC.Low Available water capacity millimetre water per centimetre soil AWC.High Available water capacity millimetre water per centimetre soil AWC.Average Available water capacity millimetre water per metre soil

what: Data for Water Balance Accounting — DataForCWB
title: Data for Water Balance Accounting — DataForCWB
text: Daily meteorological data weather station Campinas, Brazil parameters required calculating crop water balance. meteorological data belongs Agronomic Institute (IAC).

title: Data for Water Balance Accounting — DataForCWB
Data for Water Balance Accounting — DataForCWB
text: object class data.frame 129 rows 15 columns.

title: Data for Water Balance Accounting — DataForCWB
text: @format ## DataForCWB data frame 15 columns 129 rows: date date tmed Average air temperature Celsius degrees tmax Maximum air temperature Celsius degrees tmin Minimum air temperature Celsius degrees Ra Extraterrestrial solar radiation MJ m-2 day-1 Rn Net radiation MJ m-2 day-1 W Wind speed m s-1 RH Relative Humidity  % G Soil Heat Flux  MJ m-2 day-1 Rain Rain millimetres Drz Depth root zone metres AWC available water capacity (amount water field capacity permanent wilting point) millimetre water per metre soil MAD management allowed depletion (0 1) Kc Crop coefficient (0 1) Irrig Applied net irrigation millimetres @source http://www.ciiagro.org.br/

what: Typical Soil Water Characteristics for Different Soil Types (Teta) — DataForSWC
title: Typical Soil Water Characteristics for Different Soil Types (Teta) — DataForSWC
text: Soil water content field capacity permanent wilting point. Given m-3 m-3. Extracted : Allen, R.G.; Pereira, L.S.; Raes, D.; Smith, M. Crop evapotranspiration. Guidelines Computing Crop Water Requirements. Irrigation Drainage Paper 56; FAO: Rome, Italy, 1998; p. 300.

title: Typical Soil Water Characteristics for Different Soil Types (Teta) — DataForSWC
Typical Soil Water Characteristics for Different Soil Types (Teta) — DataForSWC
text: object class data.frame 9 rows 5 columns.

title: Typical Soil Water Characteristics for Different Soil Types (Teta) — DataForSWC
text: @format ## DataForSWC data frame 5 columns 9 rows: Soil type Soil Type Teta_FC_Min Minimum values soil water content field capacity Teta_FC_Max Maximum values soil water content field capacity Teta_PWP_Min Minimum values soil water content permanent wilting point Teta_PWP_Max Maximum values soil water content permanent wilting point @source https://www.fao.org/home/en/

what: Descriptive Statistics for Weather Variables — Descriptive
title: Descriptive Statistics for Weather Variables — Descriptive
text: Calculates descriptive statistics rainfall, evapotranspiration, variables.

title: Descriptive Statistics for Weather Variables — Descriptive
Descriptive Statistics for Weather Variables — Descriptive
text: Sample vector, 1-column matrix data frame rainfall, evapotranspiration, variable.

title: Descriptive Statistics for Weather Variables — Descriptive
text: dataframe : sample mean (Avg), sample median (Med), sample standard variation (SD) sample standard Error (SE) maximum value (MaxValue) minimum value (MinValue) frequency zeros (FreqZero%)

title: Descriptive Statistics for Weather Variables — Descriptive
code: Rain <- DataForCWB[, 10] Descriptive(Sample = Rain) #>   SampleSize  Avg  Med    SD   SE MaxValue MinValue FreqZero% #> 1        129 6.53 0.25 13.06 1.15    71.37        0     48.06

what: Soil Water Deficit in the Root Zone — Dinitial
title: Soil Water Deficit in the Root Zone — Dinitial
text: Estimates initial values soil water deficit.  Required initiate water balance accounting.

title: Soil Water Deficit in the Root Zone — Dinitial
Soil Water Deficit in the Root Zone — Dinitial
text: teta_FC Soil water content effective root zone field capacity \(m3/m3\) teta_Obs Soil water content effective root zone wilting point \(m3/m3\) Drz Vector, 1-column matrix data frame defining root zone depth metres.

title: Soil Water Deficit in the Root Zone — Dinitial
text: Initial soil water deficit root zone (millimetres).

title: Soil Water Deficit in the Root Zone — Dinitial
code: teta_FC <- 0.30 teta_Obs <- 0.17 Drz <- 0.3048 Dinitial(teta_FC = teta_FC, teta_Obs = teta_Obs, Drz = Drz) #> [1] 39.624

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using Hargreaves-Samani Method — ET0_HS
text: Calculates daily reference evapotranspiration amounts using Hargreaves-Samani method.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using Hargreaves-Samani Method — ET0_HS
Reference Evapotranspiration Using Hargreaves-Samani Method — ET0_HS
text: Ra vector, 1-column matrix data.frame extraterrestrial solar radiation MJ m-2 day-1. Tavg vector, 1-column matrix data.frame column daily average air temperature. Tmax vector, 1-column matrix data.frame daily maximum air temperature Celsius degrees. Tmin vector, 1-column matrix data.frame daily minimum air temperature Celsius degrees.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using Hargreaves-Samani Method — ET0_HS
text: matrix 1-column length `input values daily potential evapotranspiration values millimetres.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using Hargreaves-Samani Method — ET0_HS

what: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Penman and Monteith Method — ET0_PM
title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Penman and Monteith Method — ET0_PM
text: Calculates daily reference evapotranspiration amounts using Penman Monteith method.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Penman and Monteith Method — ET0_PM
code: ET0_PM(Tavg, Tmax, Tmin, Rn, RH, WS, G = NULL, Alt)

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Penman and Monteith Method — ET0_PM
text: Tavg vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily average air temperature. Tmax vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily maximum air temperature Celsius degrees. Tmin vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily minimum air temperature Celsius degrees. Rn vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily net radiation \(MJ m-2 day-1\). RH vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily relative Humidity \%. WS vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily wind speed \(m s-1\). G Optional. vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily soil heat flux \(MJ m-2 day-1\). Default NULL NULL assumed zero. May provided Soil_Heat_Flux Alt single number defining altitude crop's location metres.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Penman and Monteith Method — ET0_PM
text: matrix daily reference evapotranspiration amounts millimetres.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Penman and Monteith Method — ET0_PM

what: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Preistley-Taylor Method — ET0_PT
title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Preistley-Taylor Method — ET0_PT
text: Calculates daily reference evapotranspiration amounts using Priestley-Taylor method.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Preistley-Taylor Method — ET0_PT
Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Preistley-Taylor Method — ET0_PT
text: Tavg vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily average air temperature. Rn vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily net radiation \(MJ m-2 day-1\). G Optional. vector, 1-column matrix data frame daily soil heat flux \(MJ m-2 day-1\). May provided Soil_Heat_Flux Coeff Single number defining Priestley Taylor coefficient. Default 1.26.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Preistley-Taylor Method — ET0_PT
text: matrix object daily potential evapotranspiration values millimetres.

title: Reference Evapotranspiration Using the Preistley-Taylor Method — ET0_PT
